elements.content: A novel bifurcated ligand 3,5-di­(1H-benzo­[d]­imidazol-1-yl)­benzonitrile (DBIBN) has been synthesized, which reacts with Co­(II) and Mn­(II) salts to form new coordination polymers {[Co2(DBIBA)3]·Cl·9H2O} n (1) and {[Mn3(DBIBA)6]} n (2), (DBIBA = 3,5-di­(1H-benzo­[d]­imidazol-1-yl)­benzoate), in which DBIBN get hydrolyzed into DBIBA under solvothermal conditions. Both the complexes have been characterized by single-crystal X-ray crystallography (XRD), IR spectroscopy, elemental analysis, thermogravimetry, and X-ray powder diffraction (PXRD). Complex 1 is a 3D coordination polymer composed of binuclear Co­(II) units, having (4,6) connected net. On the other hand, complex 2 is a layered structure with trinuclear Mn­(II) units, which has 4-connected 44 sql topology. TGA and PXRD measurements show that the framework 1 is stable after desolvation. Desolvated framework 1 showed selective adsorption of CO2 over N2, H2, and Ar. Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements show that complex 1 exhibits weak antiferromagnetic behavior.

Both the complexes have been characterized by single-crystal X-ray crystallography (XRD), IR spectroscopy, elemental analysis, thermogravimetry, and X-ray powder diffraction (PXRD). Complex 1 is a 3D coordination polymer composed of binuclear Co(II) units, having (4,6) connected net. On the other hand, complex 2 is a layered structure with trinuclear Mn(II) units, which has 4-connected 44  sql  topology. TGA and PXRD measurements show that the framework 1 is stable after desolvation. Desolvated framework 1 showed selective adsorption of CO2 over N2, H2, and Ar. Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements show that complex 1 exhibits weak antiferromagnetic behavior.

elements.content: Two novel coordination polymers have been synthesized solvothermally using a bifurcated ligand DBIBN. Complex 1 is a 3D coordination polymer composed of binuclear Co2 units, while complex 2 is a layered structure with trinuclear Mn3 units. Selective gas adsorption and magnetic studies have been achieved in 1 and 2, respectively.
elements.clean_text: Two novel coordination polymers have been synthesized solvothermally using a bifurcated ligand DBIBN. Complex 1 is a 3D coordination polymer composed of binuclear Co2 units, while complex 2 is a layered structure with trinuclear Mn3 units. Selective gas adsorption and magnetic studies have been achieved in 1 and 2, respectively.

elements.content: Coordination polymers with various intriguing structural motifs have been extensively studied for their versatile chemical and physical properties, as well as potential applications in catalysis, adsorption, solvent exchange, magnetism, and so on. Research community has shown growing interest in the magnetic and sorption properties of coordination polymers during the past decade. The carboxylate functional group having different coordination modes has been extensively used for constructing polynuclear clusters and transmitting magnetic exchanges. Magnetic exchange is also promoted by the imidazole between paramagnetic metal centers. Therefore, if a ligand contains both carboxylate and imidazole donor moieties, it can potentially tune the magnetic exchange and lead to interesting magnetic properties. Magnetic moment is generated by metal ions, whereas the bridging ligand allows the magnetic exchange coupling between magnetic centers.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination polymers with various intriguing structural motifs have been extensively studied for their versatile chemical and physical properties, as well as potential applications in catalysis, adsorption, solvent exchange, magnetism, and so on. Research community has shown growing interest in the magnetic and sorption properties of coordination polymers during the past decade. The carboxylate functional group having different coordination modes has been extensively used for constructing polynuclear clusters and transmitting magnetic exchanges. Magnetic exchange is also promoted by the imidazole between paramagnetic metal centers. Therefore, if a ligand contains both carboxylate and imidazole donor moieties, it can potentially tune the magnetic exchange and lead to interesting magnetic properties. Magnetic moment is generated by metal ions, whereas the bridging ligand allows the magnetic exchange coupling between magnetic centers.

elements.content: Recently, porous coordination polymers (PCPs) have emerged as an important new class of materials because of their ability to selectively adsorb gases. One of the most important features of PCPs is their ability to sense incoming guest molecules, which is predominantly governed by the window dimensions, presence of functional groups in the channels, and flexibility of these materials. CO2 is a necessary intermediate product in most of the hydrogen production processes and it is also the main component of greenhouse gases. Hence, separation and storage of CO2 will become increasingly important in future.

elements.content: Herein, we have designed a new bifurcated ligand incorporating benzimidazole and cyanide functional group at their end. The cyanide group gets hydrolyzed to its corresponding carboxylate under solvothermal conditions in presence of acid or base. The important feature of this ligand is possibility of rotation about the C–N single bond (Scheme ) that can potentially lead to a number of useful structures with metal ions. Two coordination polymers, {[Co2(DBIBA)3]·Cl•9H2O} n (1) and {[Mn3(DBIBA)6]} n (2) have been synthesized under solvothermal conditions. Complex 1 shows high selectivity for CO2 adsorption, while complex 2 shows antiferromagnetic behavior.

elements.content: Reagent grade 3,5-difluorobenzonitrile and metal salts were acquired from Aldrich and used as received. All solvents, benzimidazole and K2CO3 were procured from S. D. Fine Chemicals, India. Solvents were purified prior to use following standard procedures.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

Reagent grade 3,5-difluorobenzonitrile and metal salts were acquired from Aldrich and used as received. All solvents, benzimidazole and K2CO3 were procured from S. D. Fine Chemicals, India. Solvents were purified prior to use following standard procedures.

elements.content: Infrared spectra were obtained (KBr disk, 400–4000 cm–1) using a Perkin-Elmer model 1320 spectrometer.1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were recorded using a JEOL-ECX 500 FT (500 and 125 MHz, respectively) instrument in CDCl3 with Me4Si as the internal standard. ESI mass spectra were recorded using a WATERS Q-TOF premier mass spectrometer. TGA were recorded using a Mettler Toledo (heating rate of 10◦C/min) TGA instrument. Microanalyses for the compounds were obtained using a CE-440 elemental analyzer (Exeter Analytical Inc.). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was performed using a Rigaku Rint 2000 X-ray diffractometer with CuKα radiation. Magnetic measurements were carried out in the Unitat de Mesures Magnetiques (Universitat de Barcelona) on polycrystalline samples (ca. 30 mg) with a Quantum Design SQUID MPMS-XL magnetometer equipped with a 5 T magnet. Diamagnetic corrections were calculated using Pascal’s constants and an experimental correction factor for the sample holder was applied. Gas adsorption measurements were performed using automatic volumetric BELSORP-MINI-II adsorption equipment. Prior to BET adsorption measurements, the complex 1 was immersed in dichloro methane (DCM) for 3 days at room temperature to replace guest molecules from the lattice by DCM and after that, the complex was heated to 120 °C for 12 h under vacuum to remove the solvent molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Measurements

Infrared spectra were obtained (KBr disk, 400-4000 cm-1) using a Perkin-Elmer model 1320 spectrometer.1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were recorded using a JEOL-ECX 500 FT (500 and 125 MHz, respectively) instrument in CDCl3 with Me4Si as the internal standard. ESI mass spectra were recorded using a WATERS Q-TOF premier mass spectrometer. TGA were recorded using a Mettler Toledo (heating rate of 10◦C/min) TGA instrument. Microanalyses for the compounds were obtained using a CE-440 elemental analyzer (Exeter Analytical Inc.). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was performed using a Rigaku Rint 2000 X-ray diffractometer with CuKα radiation. Magnetic measurements were carried out in the Unitat de Mesures Magnetiques (Universitat de Barcelona) on polycrystalline samples (ca. 30 mg) with a Quantum Design SQUID MPMS-XL magnetometer equipped with a 5 T magnet. Diamagnetic corrections were calculated using Pascal's constants and an experimental correction factor for the sample holder was applied. Gas adsorption measurements were performed using automatic volumetric BELSORP-MINI-II adsorption equipment. Prior to BET adsorption measurements, the complex 1 was immersed in dichloro methane (DCM) for 3 days at room temperature to replace guest molecules from the lattice by DCM and after that, the complex was heated to 120 °C for 12 h under vacuum to remove the solvent molecules.

elements.content:
Synthesis of the ligand was achieved in several steps as described below.

5-di­(1<italic toggle="yes">H</italic>-benzo­[d]­imidazol-1-yl) Benzonitrile (DBIBN)

This ligand was synthesized following a reported procedure. A mixture of benzimidazole (3.4 g, 28.8 mmol), 3,5-difluorobenzonitrile (2 g, 14.4 mmol), and K2CO3(6 g, 43.2 mmol) in 10 mL of dry DMF was heated at 80 °C for 48 h with constant stirring under nitrogen atmosphere. After it was cooled to room temperature, the mixture was poured slowly in ice-cold water (100 mL) with constant stirring to obtain a white solid that was collected by filteration and air-dried. Yield: 3.0 g, (65%). Melting point:170 °C. IR­(cm–1): 3395­(m), 3077­(m), 2236­(w), 1599(s), 1501(s), 1483­(w), 1467(s), 1406­(m), 1364­(w), 1291(s), 1248­(m), 1229(s), 1202(s), 1138­(w), 1054­(w), 1013­(w), 876­(m), 853­(w), 775­(m), 763­(m), 733(s), 686­(m), 624­(w), 498­(w), 456­(w), 425­(w). 1H NMR (CDCl3) δ (ppm): 8.23­(s, 2H, ArH), 8.00­(m, 1H, ArH), 7.93­(m, 4H, ArH), 7.59­(m, 2H, ArH), 7.43­(m, 4H, ArH). 13C NMR (CDCl3) δ (ppm): 144.33, 141.44, 139.32, 132.80, 125.65, 125.00, 124.10, 122.68, 121.48, 116.49, 109.88. Elemental analysis calcd for C21H13N5 (335.13): C, 75.26; H, 3.90; N, 20.89%. Found: C, 74.87; H, 3.80; N, 19.19%. ESI-MS: m/z (100%) 336.1186 [M + 1]+. The spectra related to this ligand are given in the as Figures S3–S6.

elements.content: A mixture of Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.07 g, 0.24 mmol), DBIBN (0.04 g, 0.12 mmol), and conc. HCl (0.1 mL) in EtOH/H2O (3 mL, 2:1 v/v) were placed in a Teflon lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. Then it was allowed to cool to room temperature at the rate of 1 °C/min. Needle-shaped reddish brown crystals of 1 were collected in 50% yield. The crystals were repeatedly washed with ethanol and air-dried. Anal. Calcd for C63H57N12O15ClCo2: C, 55.01; H, 4.17; N, 12.21%. Found: C, 54.24; H, 3.98; N, 11.91%. elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray data on complexes 1–2 were collected at 100 K on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Linear absorption coefficients, scattering factors for the atoms, and the anomalous dispersion corrections were taken from International Tables for X-ray Crystallography. Data integration and reduction were processed with SAINT software. An empirical absorption correction factor was applied to the collected reflections with SADABS and the space group was determined using XPREP. The structure was solved by direct method using SHELXTL-97 and refined on F 2 by full matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXTL-97 package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were positioned geometrically and treated as riding atoms using SHELXL default parameters. For compound 1, squeeze refinement has been performed using PLATON that shows nine water molecules per formula weight. The contribution of both the hydrogen atoms and the oxygen atoms have been incorporated in both the empirical formula and formula weight in Table . The high angle data could be obtained for compound 1 that is why in this case the data completeness was found to be 0.93. The crystal and refinement data are collected in Table , while selective bond angles and bond distances are given in Table S1, .
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Studies

Single-crystal X-ray data on complexes 1-2 were collected at 100 K on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Linear absorption coefficients, scattering factors for the atoms, and the anomalous dispersion corrections were taken from International Tables for X-ray Crystallography. Data integration and reduction were processed with SAINT software. An empirical absorption correction factor was applied to the collected reflections with SADABS and the space group was determined using XPREP. The structure was solved by direct method using SHELXTL-97 and refined on F 2 by full matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXTL-97 package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were positioned geometrically and treated as riding atoms using SHELXL default parameters. For compound 1, squeeze refinement has been performed using PLATON that shows nine water molecules per formula weight. The contribution of both the hydrogen atoms and the oxygen atoms have been incorporated in both the empirical formula and formula weight in Table . The high angle data could be obtained for compound 1 that is why in this case the data completeness was found to be 0.93. The crystal and refinement data are collected in Table , while selective bond angles and bond distances are given in Table S1, .

The ligand 3,5-di­(1H-benzo­[d]­imidazol-1-yl)­benzonitrile (DBIBN) undergoes hydrolysis under solvothermal condition to give metal bounded 3,5-di­(1H-benzo­[d]­imidazol-1-yl)­benzoate (DBIBA). The sharp peak due to nitrile stretching at 2232 cm–1 in the IR spectrum of ligand is not observed in either 1 or 2. Instead, strong absorption bands in the region, 1350–1550 cm–1 are observed indicative of coordinated carboxylates the broad bands at the region ∼3100–3350 cm–1 indicates the presence of lattice water molecules in 1 (Figures S7–S8, ). Both the imidazole N and carboxylate O atoms bind the metal ions to form coordination polymers. Once the compounds are formed, they are found to be insoluble in common organic solvents as well as in water and are stable in air. A series of coordination polymers with 3,5-di­(1H-imidazol-1-yl)­benzoic acid, similar to our ligand based on imidazole, have been reported by Sun and co-workers and a series of coordination polymers by the in situ hydrolysis of 3,5-di­(1H-imidazol-1-yl)­benzonitrile have been reported by our group.

Instead, strong absorption bands in the region, 1350-1550 cm-1 are observed indicative of coordinated carboxylates the broad bands at the region ~3100-3350 cm-1 indicates the presence of lattice water molecules in 1 (Figures S7-S8, ). Both the imidazole N and carboxylate O atoms bind the metal ions to form coordination polymers. Once the compounds are formed, they are found to be insoluble in common organic solvents as well as in water and are stable in air. elements.content: Complex 1 crystallizes in the trigonal space group P3̅1c. The asymmetric unit consists of one Co­(II) ion with 1/3 occupancy, half ligand (DBIBA–), one chloride ion (shows hydrogen bonding, see ) with 1/6 occupancy, and one and a half lattice water molecule. The structure contains a binuclear Co­(II) unit built through three bridging carboxylates, while the other three coordination sites of each metal ion are occupied by three benzimidazole N atoms forming a distorted octahedral geometry (Figure ).

X-ray Structural Studies

Complex 1 crystallizes in the trigonal space group P3̅1c. The asymmetric unit consists of one Co(II) ion with 1/3 occupancy, half ligand (DBIBA-), one chloride ion (shows hydrogen bonding, see ) with 1/6 occupancy, and one and a half lattice water molecule. The structure contains a binuclear Co(II) unit built through three bridging carboxylates, while the other three coordination sites of each metal ion are occupied by three benzimidazole N atoms forming a distorted octahedral geometry (Figure ).

elements.content: Complex 2 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit of 2 consists of two crystallographically independent Mn­(II) ions, and three DBIBA– ligands. One of the Mn­(II) ion is situated at the center of symmetry therefore has half occupancy. The structure forms a unit of three Mn­(II) ions coordinated by bridging carboxylates (Figure ). In this trinuclear cluster, each terminal metal center shows distorted octahedral MnN2O4 coordination geometry from four bridging carboxylate O (Mn–O = 2.082(6)-2.436(5) Å) and two N atoms of benzimidazole (Mn–N = 2.238(6)-2.297(6) Å). The middle metal atom shows distorted octahedral MnO6 coordination geometry from six bridging carboxylate O (Mn–O = 2.108(5)-2.314(6) Å). All the bond distances involving the metal ion are within statistical errors compared to literature values.

elements.content: The metal bound N atoms of the benzimidazole moieties extend this structure along the crystallographic a axis to form a 2-dimentional layered structure (Figure ). The linear trimeric manganese present in the structure is further extended by T-shaped π–π stacking interaction between 2D layers makes the overall structure 3D framework (Figure S2, ). Topological analysis of 2 shows that the framework consists of 4-connected sql/Shubnikov net having schlafli symbol 4462 (Figure ).

elements.content: Thermal stabilities of both the complexes were examined. Complex 1 and 2 shows high thermal stability. Complex 1 shows a weight loss of ∼12% (expected = 11.8%) in the temperature range of 80–180 °C that corresponds to loss of nine lattice water molecules. Decomposition of complex 1 takes place only above 400 °C (see ). Complex 2 also shows a high thermal stability up to 450 °C. Complete decomposition is observed beyond 450 °C (see ).

elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Complex 2 is a 2D coordination polymer built with carboxylate bridged trimeric Mn(II) units. Distance between central Mn(II) and either peripheral Mn(II) is 3.885 Å. (Figure ). As carboxylate bridging can propagate magnetic properties, this compound was subjected to variable temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements.

elements.clean_text: 7  Showing bond angle and bond distance in compound 2.

elements.content: The data for 2 were collected at an applied dc field of 0.3 T in the temperature range, 2–300 K and are shown in Figure as χT versus T plot. The χT product has a value of 14.0 cm3 K mol–1 at 300 K, in agreement with the expected value for three noninteracting Mn­(II) ions with g = 2.1 and S = 5/2. With lowering of temperature, the χT product decreases slightly, until a sharp decrease is observed below 100 K. The value reaches to 4.2 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K, as expected for a ground state spin of S = 5/2. The coupling between metal centers is weakly antiferromagnetic, as expected for Mn­(II) ions bridged by carboxylate ligands. The experimental susceptibility data can be modeled using the Kambe or equivalent operator approach. The spin Hamiltonian of eq can be analytically solved to find the eigen-values of each spin level, which can in-turn be used to write a Van Vleck equation (eq ) to model the magnetic susceptibility data. The Ŝ i terms of the Hamiltonian are the spin operators on each i metal, as labeled in the model shown in Figure . The equation obtained was used to fit the experimental data, resulting in the best fit shown in Figure as a solid line. The best fitting parameters were J 1 = −1.07 cm–1 and g = 2.1, with J2 kept fixed as J2 = 0. This is confirmed by the reduced magnetization data measured at 2 K, as shown in Figure . The magnetization follows the Brillouin law for an S = 5/2 with g = 2.0, shown as a solid line in Figure , reaching a saturation at 5 T at a value of M/NμB = 5. Ĥ = − 2 J 1 [ Ŝ 1 · Ŝ 2 + Ŝ 2 · Ŝ 3 ] − 2 J 2 [ Ŝ 1 · Ŝ 3 ]

elements.content: Compound 1 being quite porous with 32.8% of void volume, was subjected to gas adsorption studies. The gas adsorption experiments were carried out using N2, H2, and CO2 under different experimental conditions. The compound was activated by immersing in DCM for 3 days followed by heating at 120 °C for 12 h. Framework remains intact after desolvation that is confirmed by PXRD measurements (Figures S9, ). Gas adsorption studies were conducted at low pressure on this desolvated 1 with N2 at 77 K, CO2 at 195, 273, and 298 K, and H2 at 77 K respectively (Figure ). N2 and H2 did not diffuse into the pores of 1 even at 77 K and showed only surface adsorption (2.5 cm3 g–1 for N2 and 7.5 cm3 g–1 for H2 at P/Po = 1). Although the channel size (∼6 Å2) is large enough compared to the kinetic diameter of N2 and H2 (2.9 and 3.6 Å, respectively), this may be attributed to the 1D channel systems running along crystallographic c axis (Figure ) in all the frameworks, and there are no additional effective channels along the a or b axis. Therefore, at very low temperatures (77 K), N2 or H2 molecules probably interact strongly with pore aperture and block other molecules to pass through, and resulting only in surface adsorption.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Adsorption Studies

Compound 1 being quite porous with 32.8% of void volume, was subjected to gas adsorption studies. The gas adsorption experiments were carried out using N2, H2, and CO2 under different experimental conditions. The compound was activated by immersing in DCM for 3 days followed by heating at 120 °C for 12 h. Framework remains intact after desolvation that is confirmed by PXRD measurements (Figures S9, ). Gas adsorption studies were conducted at low pressure on this desolvated 1 with N2 at 77 K, CO2 at 195, 273, and 298 K, and H2 at 77 K respectively (Figure ). N2 and H2 did not diffuse into the pores of 1 even at 77 K and showed only surface adsorption (2.5 cm3 g-1 for N2 and 7.5 cm3 g-1 for H2 at P/Po = 1). Although the channel size (~6 Å2) is large enough compared to the kinetic diameter of N2 and H2 (2.9 and 3.6 Å, respectively), this may be attributed to the 1D channel systems running along crystallographic c axis (Figure ) in all the frameworks, and there are no additional effective channels along the a or b axis. Therefore, at very low temperatures (77 K), N2 or H2 molecules probably interact strongly with pore aperture and block other molecules to pass through, and resulting only in surface adsorption.

elements.content: Different gas adsorption isotherms with CO2 uptakes.
elements.clean_text: 10  Different gas adsorption isotherms with CO2 uptakes.

elements.content: However, CO2 adsorption experiment for 1 showed typical type I adsorption isotherm at 195, 273, and 298 K confirming the microporous nature of 1. The maximum CO2 uptakes at 1 atm and 195 K for desolvated 1 are 140.5 cm3 g–1 with Langmuir surface area 794 m2 g–1, calculated from CO2 profile using the Langmuir equation. At 273 and 298 K the adsorbate amount decreased to 52.1 cm3 g–1 and 44.2 cm3 g–1 respectively, which are moderately high and comparable to the recently reported values. To study the selectivity of desolvated 1 at 195 K, we have performed adsorption isotherm measurements of N2, and Ar, which suggests an excellent selective nature for CO2 at the same temperature, 195 K (Figures S13, ). Therefore, nature of channels and interior wall composed of linker and metal ions that can interact with linear CO2 molecules, could be the crucial factors for such high selectivity.

elements.content: Two new coordination polymers have been synthesized with DBIBN ligand under in situ cyanide hydrolysis. Compound 1 shows reversible and selective adsorption of CO2 at low pressure, while compound 2 shows weak antiferromagnetic behavior. Possible extension of this work is in progress with other transition and lanthanide metals in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Two new coordination polymers have been synthesized with DBIBN ligand under in situ cyanide hydrolysis. Compound 1 shows reversible and selective adsorption of CO2 at low pressure, while compound 2 shows weak antiferromagnetic behavior. Possible extension of this work is in progress with other transition and lanthanide metals in our laboratory.

5-di­(1<italic toggle="yes">H</italic>-benzo­[d]­imidazol-1-yl) Benzonitrile (DBIBN)

This ligand was synthesized following a reported procedure. A mixture of benzimidazole (3.4 g, 28.8 mmol), 3,5-difluorobenzonitrile (2 g, 14.4 mmol), and K2CO3(6 g, 43.2 mmol) in 10 mL of dry DMF was heated at 80 °C for 48 h with constant stirring under nitrogen atmosphere. After it was cooled to room temperature, the mixture was poured slowly in ice-cold water (100 mL) with constant stirring to obtain a white solid that was collected by filteration and air-dried. Thermal stabilities of both the complexes were examined. Complex 1 and 2 shows high thermal stability. Complex 1 shows a weight loss of ∼12% (expected = 11.8%) in the temperature range of 80–180 °C that corresponds to loss of nine lattice water molecules. Decomposition of complex 1 takes place only above 400 °C (see ). Complex 2 also shows a high thermal stability up to 450 °C. Complete decomposition is observed beyond 450 °C (see ).

Gas Adsorption Studies

Compound 1 being quite porous with 32.8% of void volume, was subjected to gas adsorption studies. The gas adsorption experiments were carried out using N2, H2, and CO2 under different experimental conditions. The compound was activated by immersing in DCM for 3 days followed by heating at 120 °C for 12 h. Framework remains intact after desolvation that is confirmed by PXRD measurements (Figures S9, ). Gas adsorption studies were conducted at low pressure on this desolvated 1 with N2 at 77 K, CO2 at 195, 273, and 298 K, and H2 at 77 K respectively (Figure ). N2 and H2 did not diffuse into the pores of 1 even at 77 K and showed only surface adsorption (2.5 cm3 g–1 for N2 and 7.5 cm3 g–1 for H2 at P/Po = 1). Although the channel size (∼6 Å2) is large enough compared to the kinetic diameter of N2 and H2 (2.9 and 3.6 Å, respectively), this may be attributed to the 1D channel systems running along crystallographic c axis (Figure ) in all the frameworks, and there are no additional effective channels along the a or b axis. Therefore, at very low temperatures (77 K), N2 or H2 molecules probably interact strongly with pore aperture and block other molecules to pass through, and resulting only in surface adsorption.

However, CO2 adsorption experiment for 1 showed typical type I adsorption isotherm at 195, 273, and 298 K confirming the microporous nature of 1. The maximum CO2 uptakes at 1 atm and 195 K for desolvated 1 are 140.5 cm3 g–1 with Langmuir surface area 794 m2 g–1, calculated from CO2 profile using the Langmuir equation. At 273 and 298 K the adsorbate amount decreased to 52.1 cm3 g–1 and 44.2 cm3 g–1 respectively, which are moderately high and comparable to the recently reported values. To study the selectivity of desolvated 1 at 195 K, we have performed adsorption isotherm measurements of N2, and Ar, which suggests an excellent selective nature for CO2 at the same temperature, 195 K (Figures S13, ). Therefore, nature of channels and interior wall composed of linker and metal ions that can interact with linear CO2 molecules, could be the crucial factors for such high selectivity.
